protocol_name: The process of introducing safety attitudes questionnaire (SAQ)
protocol_name_html: The process of introducing safety attitudes questionnaire (SAQ)
manuscript_citation: Li Y, Zhao X, Zhang X, Zhang C, Ma H, Jiao M, Li X, Gao L, Hao M, Lv J, Zhao Y, Cui Y, Liu J, Huang Z, Shi W, Wu Q, Yin M (2017) Validation study of the safety attitudes questionnaire (SAQ) in public hospitals of Heilongjiang province, China. PLoS ONE 12(6): e0179486. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0179486

components.data: Based on this survey, the selected instrument for data collection was the short form generic safety attitudes questionnaire (SAQ), which included 30 items.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Based on this survey, the selected instrument for data collection was the short form generic safety attitudes questionnaire (SAQ), which included 30 items.

components.data: Four experts with backgrounds in medical and public health management translated the original questionnaire into Chinese.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Four experts with backgrounds in medical and public health management translated the original questionnaire into Chinese.

components.data: The SAQ was translated by English speaking medical graduates into English to confirm that the meaning of the original questionnaire was unchanged.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The SAQ was translated by English speaking medical graduates into English to confirm that the meaning of the original questionnaire was unchanged.

components.data: Translate the Chinese questionnaire into English
components.name: Section

source_data.section: Translate the Chinese questionnaire into English

components.data: Five experts consisting of a public health professional, nurse, physician, researcher, and healthcare administrator then reviewed the questionnaire and offered feedback to ensure cross-cultural consistency and applicability in China. Then, the initial version was formed.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Five experts consisting of a public health professional, nurse, physician, researcher, and healthcare administrator then reviewed the questionnaire and offered feedback to ensure cross-cultural consistency and applicability in China. Then, the initial version was formed.

components.data: A survey among Harbin medical staff was conducted with the initial version. Based on the analysis of the survey results, inappropriate parts of the questionnaire were revised to arrive at the validation-version.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: A survey among Harbin medical staff was conducted with the initial version. Based on the analysis of the survey results, inappropriate parts of the questionnaire were revised to arrive at the validation-version.

components.data: Data collection was conducted in July and August 2014 in Heilongjiang province. The questionnaire was distributed during staff meetings in hospital outpatient departments, inpatient departments, medical-technology departments, and some administrative departments.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Data collection was conducted in July and August 2014 in Heilongjiang province. The questionnaire was distributed during staff meetings in hospital outpatient departments, inpatient departments, medical-technology departments, and some administrative departments.

components.data: All data were analysed using SAS 9.3 (SAS Institute, Cary, NC, USA). The methods included Pearson’s correlation analysis, Cronbach’s α coefficient and confirmatory factor analysis (CFA).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: All data were analysed using SAS 9.3 (SAS Institute, Cary, NC, USA). The methods included Pearson’s correlation analysis, Cronbach’s α coefficient and confirmatory factor analysis (CFA).

components.data: Final version of the Chinese SAQ short
components.name: Section

source_data.section: Final version of the Chinese SAQ short
